# _The Staircase_

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

For the book, see [The Staircase (book)](/wiki/The_Staircase_\(book\) "The
Staircase \(book\)"). For other uses, see [Staircase
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Staircase_\(disambiguation\) "Staircase
\(disambiguation\)").

The Staircase  
---

Staircase.png](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/d/dd/The_Staircase.png)](/wiki/File:The_Staircase.png)Promotional
poster

_**The Staircase**_ ([French](/wiki/French_language "French language"):
_Soupçons_ , [lit.](/wiki/Literal_translation "Literal translation")
''Suspicions''; also known as _Death on the Staircase_) is a 2004 French
television [miniseries](/wiki/Miniseries "Miniseries") by [Jean-Xavier de
Lestrade](/wiki/Jean-Xavier_de_Lestrade "Jean-Xavier de Lestrade") documenting
the trial of [Michael
Peterson](/wiki/Michael_Peterson_\(author_and_convicted_criminal\) "Michael
Peterson \(author and convicted criminal\)"), convicted of murdering his wife,
[Kathleen Peterson](/wiki/Kathleen_Peterson "Kathleen Peterson").

Following from de Lestrade's Oscar-winning _[Murder on a Sunday
Morning](/wiki/Murder_on_a_Sunday_Morning "Murder on a Sunday Morning")_ ,
filming began soon after Peterson's indictment. Camera crews were given access
to the accused's extended family, the defense attorneys, and the courtroom.[3]
The film features a brief appearance by [Mike Nifong](/wiki/Mike_Nifong "Mike
Nifong"), a future figure in the [Duke lacrosse case](/wiki/Duke_lacrosse_case
"Duke lacrosse case"), working with the team prosecuting Peterson.

An abbreviated version was broadcast as special two-hour presentation of
American news show _[Primetime Thursday](/wiki/Primetime_\(U.S._TV_program\)
"Primetime \(U.S. TV program\)")_ on July 22, 2004.[4] The miniseries was
completed in September 2004,[5] and premiered in October on
[Canal+](/wiki/Canal%2B "Canal+"),[6] from January 10–14, 2005, on BBC Four
(as part of its _[Storyville](/wiki/Storyville_\(TV_series\) "Storyville \(TV
series\)")_ documentary series),[7] and from April 4–25 on Sundance
Channel.[8][9]

The BBC featured an interview with Lestrade in 2005.[10]

## Contents

  * 1 Plot
  * 2 Reception
  * 3 Sequels
  * 4 Legacy
  * 5 References
  * 6 External links

## Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Staircase&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Plot")]

In December 2001, novelist Michael Peterson called to report that his wife
Kathleen had fallen down a set of stairs in their [Forest
Hills](/wiki/Forest_Hills_Historic_District_\(Durham,_North_Carolina\) "Forest
Hills Historic District \(Durham, North Carolina\)") mansion and died. The
authorities disbelieved Peterson's story that Kathleen had fallen while drunk
and concluded instead that he had bludgeoned her to death, most likely with a
fireplace poker which was discovered missing from the house. Peterson was soon
charged with murder. The film details the ensuing case from the point of view
of Peterson and his defense team, led by David Rudolf. During the trial it is
discovered that while Peterson was living in Germany, a family friend died
from an [intra-cerebral haemorrhage](/wiki/Stroke "Stroke"), followed by the
body falling down stairs after collapsing, which resulted in similar head
injuries to those sustained by Peterson's wife. An investigation by German
police and US military authorities concluded that the death was accidental,
and Peterson ended up adopting the woman's two daughters. The prosecution
introduce this death into the trial as an incident giving Peterson the idea of
how to "fake" Kathleen's accident. During the trial, Peterson's daughters
stand steadfastly by their father. The prosecution argues that Kathleen had
discovered that Michael was bisexual and had been having affairs with men,
which led to an argument in which he bludgeoned her to death. Peterson claimed
that his wife knew about his sexuality and that they had an [open
marriage](/wiki/Open_marriage "Open marriage"). He claims to have been outside
by their pool when Kathleen fell down the stairs and injured herself. A
defense team recreation shows that it would have been possible for Peterson to
have missed his wife's cries for help had he been by the pool. The jury
ultimately convicts Peterson.

## Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Staircase&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Reception")]

Reviews for _The Staircase_ were generally positive. The film received an
"exceptional quality" rating (8.5 out of 10) from Documentary-Review.com based
on 9 reviews.[11] It won a [Peabody Award](/wiki/Peabody_Award "Peabody
Award") in 2005.[12]

## Sequels[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Staircase&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Sequels")]

In April 2012, it was revealed that Lestrade was working on four follow-up
film to _The Staircase_ for French broadcaster [Canal+](/wiki/Canal%2B
"Canal+"),[13] after [Michael
Peterson](/wiki/Michael_Peterson_\(author_and_convicted_criminal\) "Michael
Peterson \(author and convicted criminal\)") was released from jail, pending a
retrial. The sequel, subtitled "Last Chance," premiered at the [International
Documentary Film Festival
Amsterdam](/wiki/International_Documentary_Film_Festival_Amsterdam
"International Documentary Film Festival Amsterdam") (IDFA)[14] in November
2012.[15] It aired on Canal+ on January 30, 2013,[16] and on BBC Four's
_Storyville_ on February 4.[17] Sundance Channel aired a shorter alternative
cut, presenting "Last Chance" as two new episodes of the original miniseries,
airing March 4 and March 11, 2013.[5][18]

On November 23, 2015, Lestrade announced a second follow-up film at the IDFA
Forum.[19] Originally announced as _Staircase III_ , the film documents the
story of Peterson's final trial, set for early 2016. The film was commissioned
by Canal+. _Last Chance_ producer Matthieu Belghiti of What's Up Films was
also attached.[20] It was later picked up by [Netflix](/wiki/Netflix
"Netflix") to be released as three new episodes of the miniseries, together
with the previous ten episodes on June 8, 2018.[21] The first of the new
episodes premiered April 28, 2018, at the [Tribeca Film
Festival](/wiki/Tribeca_Film_Festival "Tribeca Film Festival").[22]

## Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Staircase&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Legacy")]

The 2017 sitcom _[Trial& Error](/wiki/Trial_%26_Error_\(TV_series\) "Trial &
Error \(TV series\)")_ parodies this documentary and the details of the case.
